clinical_study.official_title: Immediate vs. Delayed Stenting After Primary Percutaneous Reperfusion in ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this research project is to improve how we treat heart attacks. The study will assess whether it might not be better to wait a few hours before implanting the coronary stent into the coronary artery rather than implanting it immediately, in order to allow the drugs to completely dissolve the clot. This might help to reduce the risks of the clot migrating and damaging the heart. By delaying coronary stent implantation, we hope to be able to reduce the size of the infarction and reduce the risk of suffering from heart failure following a heart attack.

detailed_description.textblock: The PRIMACY trial seeks to assess whether a strategy of delayed stent implantation combined with adjunctive anticoagulation is superior to immediate stent implantation at improving cardiovascular outcomes in patients with mechanically reperfused ST-elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI). The investigators hypothesize that delayed stent implantation combined with systemic anticoagulation and maximal antiplatelet therapy will reduce the combined occurrence of cardiac death, non-fatal myocardial infarction, congestive heart failure, and target vessel revascularization at 90 days.

primary_outcome.measure: The combined occurence of cardiac death, non-fatal myocardial infarction, congestive heart failure, and urgent target vessel revascularization

secondary_outcome.description: As defined by the Bleeding Academic Research Consortium (BARC).

arm_group.description: the stent selection (bare metal vs drug eluting) and implantation will be performed as recommended by current practice guidelines.

participants randomised to delayed stenting will be treated with GPIIb-IIIa inhibitors for 12-18 hours after reperfusion followed by anticoagulation for until the control angiogram, expected no sooner than 18-24 hours after the index reperfusion.

intervention.description: Percutaneous coronary intervention: reperfusion with a thrombectomy catheter or a small balloon angioplasty catheter, followed by coronary stenting
